item001.title: Moong Dal Cheela (High Protein)
item001.description: Savory pancakes made from ground sprouted moong lentils, packed with greens. Significance: Excellent source of plant-based protein for muscle maintenance and sustained energy, low on the glycemic index making it good for managing blood sugar.
item001.healthBenefit: Moong Dal Cheela delivers approximately 15g of protein per standard serving (2 medium cheelas) and is rich in fiber, promoting satiety.
instructions: Soak and sprout moong dal overnight for best results.
Grind the sprouted dal, water, spinach, chili, and ginger into a smooth batter.
Stir in cumin seeds and salt.
Heat a non-stick tawa over medium heat and lightly grease with oil.
Pour a ladleful of batter onto the tawa and spread it in a circular motion.
Cook for 3-4 minutes until the base is golden brown.
Flip and cook the other side until done.
Serve hot with mint chutney.

item002.title: Oats Upma with Vegetables
item002.description: A whole-grain twist on the classic Upma, using rolled oats instead of semolina. Significance: High in soluble fiber (beta-glucan) which is excellent for lowering bad cholesterol and maintaining heart health.
item002.healthBenefit: One serving provides about 5g of fiber, helping regulate blood sugar levels and improving gut health.
instructions: Dry roast the rolled oats in a pan for 3 minutes until fragrant; set aside.
Heat oil in the same pan over medium heat.
Add mustard seeds and asafoetida; let them splutter.
Add chopped vegetables and sauté until tender-crisp (5-7 minutes).
Add 1.5 cups of water and salt; bring to a boil.
Slowly stir in the dry-roasted oats, ensuring no lumps form.
Cover and cook on low heat for 5 minutes until all water is absorbed.
Garnish with coriander and serve.

item003.title: South Indian Idli (Steamed)
item003.description: Soft, fluffy, and fermented steamed cakes made from rice and lentils. Significance: Fermentation increases B vitamin content and makes the nutrients more bioavailable; being steamed, it's extremely low in fat.
item003.healthBenefit: A naturally probiotic-rich food from fermentation, supporting gut flora balance. Low in fat (<1g per idli).
instructions: Soak rice, dal, and fenugreek seeds separately for 5-6 hours.
Grind the dal and rice separately into a smooth batter, adding just enough water.
Mix both batters together with salt in a large container.
Allow the batter to ferment in a warm place for 8-12 hours until doubled.
Gently mix the batter without adding water.
Grease the idli moulds lightly.
Fill the moulds 3/4 full and steam in an idli cooker for 12-15 minutes.
Let them cool slightly before unmoulding. Serve with sambar.

item004.title: Scrambled Eggs (Anda Bhurji) with Whole Wheat Toast
item004.description: Indian style spicy scrambled eggs cooked with onions and tomatoes. Significance: Eggs are a complete protein source, essential for tissue repair and muscle building. Whole wheat toast adds complex carbohydrates for sustained energy.
item004.healthBenefit: High biological value protein (approx. 18g per 2-egg serving) aiding recovery. Contains choline for brain health.
instructions: Whisk the eggs in a bowl with salt and pepper.
Heat oil in a pan over medium heat.
Sauté onions until translucent (3 minutes). Add tomatoes and cook until soft.
Add turmeric and chili powder; cook for 30 seconds.
Pour in the whisked eggs and let them set slightly (1 minute).
Scramble the eggs gently with a spatula until cooked to your liking.
Toast the whole wheat bread slices.
Serve the Bhurji hot alongside the toast.

item005.title: Banana Peanut Butter Oatmeal (Vegan)
item005.description: Creamy rolled oats cooked in water or plant milk, topped with banana and peanut butter. Significance: A classic high-fiber breakfast that promotes digestive regularity and keeps you full until lunch, making it ideal for weight management.
item005.healthBenefit: Delivers significant soluble and insoluble fiber (around 9g), supporting a healthy gut microbiome.
ingredients: 1 cup water or unsweetened soy milk
instructions: Combine oats, liquid, and chia seeds in a saucepan.
Bring to a gentle boil, then reduce heat to low.
Simmer for 5-7 minutes, stirring occasionally, until creamy.
Stir in cinnamon powder.
Transfer to a bowl.
Top with sliced banana and drizzle with peanut butter.
Let it sit for 2 minutes to slightly melt the peanut butter.
Enjoy warm.

item006.title: Masala Oats with Sprouts (Low Carb Alternative)
item006.description: Quick-cooking oats seasoned with Indian spices and mixed with protein-rich sprouts. Significance: Using sprouted moong adds significant protein and fiber, lowering the overall glycemic load compared to plain oats, which is beneficial for energy stability.
item006.healthBenefit: The sprouts contribute about 4g of extra protein and enzymes that aid digestion, balancing the carbohydrate base.
instructions: Heat mustard oil in a small pot.
Add a pinch of turmeric and the mixed sprouts; sauté for 2 minutes.
Add water and salt; bring to a boil.
Stir in the quick oats and garam masala.
Reduce heat and simmer until oats are cooked (about 3-4 minutes).
Stir well to combine.
Serve immediately with a squeeze of fresh lemon juice.

item007.title: Besan Toast Sandwich (Vegan Option)
item007.description: Thick slices of bread dipped in a spiced chickpea flour batter and shallow-fried. Significance: Besan (chickpea flour) adds plant protein and complex carbs, offering a more balanced macronutrient profile than plain bread toast.
item007.healthBenefit: Provides about 10g of protein from the besan batter, enhancing the meal's staying power.
instructions: In a bowl, whisk besan, water, turmeric, ajwain, and salt until a smooth, thick batter forms.
Heat a flat pan over medium heat and lightly grease it.
Dip one slice of bread completely into the batter, ensuring it's coated on both sides.
Place the dipped slice onto the hot pan.
Drizzle a few drops of oil around the edges.
Cook for 3-4 minutes until golden brown, then flip and cook the other side.
Repeat with the remaining slices.
Serve hot.

item008.title: Fruit & Yogurt Smoothie Bowl (Dairy-Free)
item008.description: A blended smoothie base made with frozen fruits and plant-based yogurt, topped with seeds. Significance: Excellent source of antioxidants and probiotics for gut health; dairy-free option suitable for lactose intolerance.
item008.healthBenefit: Contains beneficial live cultures from the yogurt and is packed with Vitamin C from berries for immune support.
instructions: Combine frozen berries, frozen banana, almond yogurt, flax seeds, and spinach (if using) in a high-speed blender.
Blend starting on low speed and gradually increasing to high until completely smooth and thick.
If too thick, add a splash more liquid; blend again.
Pour the mixture into a serving bowl.
Drizzle with honey or maple syrup, if desired.
Garnish with extra seeds or fresh fruit slices.
Consume immediately for the best texture.

item009.title: Ragi Dosa with Coconut Chutney
item009.description: Thin crepes made from nutrient-dense Ragi (finger millet) flour. Significance: Ragi is one of the richest sources of calcium among millets, crucial for bone health, and is naturally gluten-free.
item009.healthBenefit: Contains nearly 350mg of calcium per 100g of flour, significantly contributing to daily intake for bone density.
ingredients: For Chutney: 1 cup fresh coconut, 1 green chili, ginger
instructions: In a bowl, whisk together Ragi flour, rice flour, and salt.
Gradually add water, whisking continuously to form a thin, pourable batter (like crepe batter). Let it rest for 15 minutes.
While resting, grind chutney ingredients with a little water and salt.
Heat a cast-iron tawa over medium-high heat; grease lightly.
Pour a ladleful of batter onto the center and quickly spread it out in a circular motion.
Drizzle a few drops of oil around the edges.
Cook until the edges lift and the bottom is crisp (about 2-3 minutes).
Flip and cook briefly on the other side. Serve with chutney.

item010.title: Spiced Vegetable Omelette (2-Egg)
item010.description: A quick, nutrient-dense omelette packed with finely chopped vegetables. Significance: Provides high-quality protein and essential micronutrients from the vegetables, supporting satiety and minimizing mid-morning hunger pangs.
item010.healthBenefit: An excellent source of Choline (from egg yolks), vital for cognitive function and brain health.
instructions: In a bowl, whisk eggs with milk/water, salt, and pepper until frothy.
Gently fold in the chopped vegetables.
Heat oil/ghee in a small non-stick pan over medium heat.
Pour the egg mixture into the pan.
Let the edges set for about 1 minute without stirring.
Cover the pan and cook on low heat for 4-5 minutes until the top is mostly set.
Fold the omelette in half or serve flat.
Serve immediately.

item001.title: Whole Wheat Roti with Palak Dal (High Fiber)
item001.description: A classic North Indian meal pairing whole wheat flatbread with spinach-infused lentil stew. Significance: The combination provides complex carbohydrates, complete protein from the dal, and high fiber, which aids slow digestion and stabilizes blood sugar for the afternoon.
item001.healthBenefit: Dal provides essential iron and protein, while spinach significantly boosts Vitamin K and folate intake.
ingredients: Turmeric, salt, red chili powder to taste
instructions: Pressure cook dal with turmeric and salt until very soft (about 3 whistles).
In a small pan, heat oil/ghee, add cumin seeds and hing; let them splutter.
Add chopped tomato and sauté until mushy.
Add chopped spinach and cook until wilted (3-4 minutes).
Mash the cooked dal slightly and add it to the tempering mixture.
Add water to adjust consistency, bring to a boil, and simmer for 5 minutes.
Prepare rotis on a dry tawa until cooked through.
Serve hot dal with the rotis.

item002.title: Chicken and Mixed Vegetable Stir-fry (Low Carb)
item002.description: Lean chicken breast pieces quickly tossed with high-fiber, non-starchy vegetables. Significance: Maximizes protein intake while minimizing carbohydrates, ideal for weight management or those monitoring carb intake closely.
item002.healthBenefit: Chicken provides lean protein (approx. 30g per serving), promoting muscle synthesis, while the vegetables add volume with few calories.
instructions: Marinate chicken cubes with half the ginger-garlic paste, pepper, and 1 tsp soy sauce for 10 minutes.
Heat sesame oil in a wok or large pan over high heat.
Add the marinated chicken and stir-fry until golden brown and cooked through (5-7 minutes). Remove from pan.
Add the remaining ginger-garlic paste to the pan and sauté for 30 seconds.
Add broccoli and bell peppers; stir-fry for 4 minutes until tender-crisp.
Return the chicken to the pan.
Add the remaining soy sauce and toss everything together for 1 minute.
Serve immediately without rice or bread.

item003.title: Quinoa Pulao with Mixed Sprouts and Paneer
item003.description: A wholesome, gluten-free grain dish using quinoa cooked with vegetables and cottage cheese. Significance: Quinoa is a complete protein and high in minerals like magnesium, beneficial for heart rhythm and bone health.
item003.healthBenefit: Quinoa provides all nine essential amino acids, making it a superior plant-based protein source compared to traditional rice.
instructions: Rinse quinoa thoroughly under cold water; set aside.
Heat oil in a pot; add whole spices (bay leaf, cloves, cinnamon) and cumin seeds.
Sauté for 30 seconds until fragrant.
Add the rinsed quinoa and sprouts; sauté for 2 minutes.
Add water and salt; bring to a boil.
Cover, reduce heat to low, and simmer for 15 minutes until water is absorbed.
Fluff with a fork. Gently fold in the cubed paneer.
Cover again for 5 minutes to heat the paneer through. Serve warm.

item004.title: Vegetable Raita with Bajra Roti (Heart Healthy)
item004.description: A cooling side dish of yogurt mixed with grated cucumber and spices, paired with millet flatbread. Significance: Bajra (pearl millet) is rich in unsaturated fats and fiber, known to support cardiovascular health by improving lipid profiles.
item004.healthBenefit: Bajra is high in complex carbohydrates that release energy slowly, preventing sharp insulin spikes.
ingredients: Salt and a pinch of black salt for raita
Bajra flour and water for rotis
instructions: Prepare Bajra dough by mixing flour with hot water and kneading well. Roll into rotis and cook on a medium-hot tawa until done.
For the Raita: Whisk the yogurt until smooth.
Squeeze excess water from the grated cucumber and add it to the yogurt.
Stir in cilantro, cumin powder, salt, and black salt.
Serve the cooling raita immediately alongside the hot bajra rotis.
It is traditionally eaten with a simple vegetable curry or pickle (not included in nutrition est.).

item005.title: Lentil and Vegetable Soup (Immunity Boost)
item005.description: A light yet filling soup made with mixed lentils (like masoor and moong) and immune-boosting vegetables like carrots and ginger. Significance: High in zinc and iron from lentils, crucial for a robust immune system response.
item005.healthBenefit: Lentils are a powerhouse of B vitamins and minerals that support cellular repair and immune function.
instructions: In a large pot, combine washed lentils, broth/water, diced carrot, celery, ginger, turmeric, and coriander powder.
Bring the mixture to a boil, then reduce heat to low.
Cover and simmer for 30-40 minutes, or until lentils are very tender.
Use an immersion blender to partially blend the soup for a thicker texture, leaving some whole lentils.
Season with salt and pepper to taste.
Simmer for another 5 minutes.
Serve hot, optionally garnished with fresh parsley.

item006.title: Fish Curry (Kadhi) with Brown Rice (Omega-3 Rich)
item006.description: Lean white fish cooked in a light, tangy yogurt-based gravy (Kadhi style, using less starch). Significance: Provides essential Omega-3 fatty acids beneficial for heart health and reducing inflammation.
item006.healthBenefit: Omega-3s (EPA/DHA) support brain function and cardiovascular protection. Fish protein is easily digestible.
ingredients: Mustard seeds, curry leaves, turmeric, green chili
instructions: Marinate fish pieces lightly with salt and turmeric for 10 minutes.
Whisk yogurt/buttermilk with besan and a little water until smooth; set aside.
Heat mustard oil; splutter mustard seeds and add curry leaves and chili.
Add turmeric and gently place fish pieces; sear on both sides for 2 minutes each.
Pour in the yogurt-besan mixture and add salt; stir gently.
Bring to a simmer (do not boil rapidly). Cook covered for 10-12 minutes until fish is cooked.
Serve the hot curry over the cooked brown rice.

item007.title: Vegetable Poha with Peanuts (Light Meal)
item007.description: Flattened rice sautéed with mustard seeds, turmeric, vegetables, and crunchy peanuts. Significance: A quick, light meal rich in iron and easily digestible carbohydrates, perfect for a moderate midday energy boost without feeling heavy.
item007.healthBenefit: Poha is known to be iron-rich. The small amount of fat from peanuts aids in the absorption of fat-soluble vitamins present in the dish.
instructions: Rinse poha quickly under water and let it sit for 5 minutes to fluff up.
Heat oil in a wide pan; add mustard seeds and allow to splutter.
Add onions and peas; sauté until tender (about 4 minutes).
Stir in turmeric powder.
Add the fluffed poha and salt. Mix very gently so the grains don't break.
Cook for 2 minutes. Stir in roasted peanuts.
Squeeze fresh lemon juice over the top before serving.

item008.title: Chana Masala with Cucumber Salad (Vegan Protein)
item008.description: Chickpeas cooked in a spicy tomato-onion gravy. Significance: Chickpeas are high in fiber and plant protein, excellent for sustained energy and managing cholesterol levels.
item008.healthBenefit: A single cup of cooked chickpeas contains about 15g of protein and 12g of dietary fiber.
ingredients: Chana masala powder, ginger-garlic paste, turmeric
instructions: Heat oil, add onion puree and cook until golden brown (10-12 minutes).
Add ginger-garlic paste, cook for 1 minute.
Add tomato puree, chana masala, turmeric, and salt; cook until oil separates.
Add the cooked chickpeas and water; bring to a boil.
Simmer covered for 15 minutes to allow flavors to meld.
While simmering, slice cucumber and toss with salt and pepper for a simple side salad.
Serve Chana Masala hot with the salad.

item009.title: Spinach and Lentil Salad (Skinny Fat Friendly)
item009.description: A hearty salad mixing cooked lentils (like masoor), sautéed spinach, and a light lemon dressing. Significance: High nutrient density with controlled calories and good protein/fiber ratio makes it excellent for improving body composition (skinny-fat friendly).
item009.healthBenefit: The high fiber content (from lentils and spinach) promotes satiety, reducing overall calorie intake without sacrificing nutrition.
instructions: Cook masoor dal until tender but still holding shape; drain well.
In a pan, quickly wilt the spinach leaves with a teaspoon of water; set aside.
In a large bowl, combine the cooked lentils, wilted spinach, and chopped red onion.
In a small cup, whisk together lemon juice, olive oil, chaat masala, salt, and pepper to create the dressing.
Pour the dressing over the salad mixture.
Toss everything gently until well combined.
Serve immediately or chill for later.

item010.title: Vegetable Masala Omelette Wrap (Non-Veg)
item010.description: A fluffy omelette loaded with finely chopped vegetables, wrapped in a single wheat tortilla. Significance: Provides a quick, balanced meal containing protein, healthy fats, and fiber from the veggies, suitable for an active lifestyle.
item010.healthBenefit: Offers superior satiety due to high protein content, helping control portion sizes for lunch.
ingredients: 1/4 cup mixed finely chopped veggies (carrot, capsicum)
instructions: Whisk eggs with spices and finely chopped vegetables.
Heat oil in a pan and pour the egg mixture.
Cook on low heat until set, sprinkling cheese if using.
Warm the whole wheat tortilla on a separate dry pan for 30 seconds per side.
Carefully transfer the cooked omelette onto the tortilla.
Fold or roll the tortilla around the omelette.
Serve immediately as a wrap.

item001.title: Tofu Bhurji with Jowar Roti (Vegan, Gluten-Free)
item001.description: Crumbled tofu sautéed with onions, tomatoes, and spices, similar to scrambled eggs but entirely plant-based. Significance: Excellent source of soy protein and isoflavones; pairing with Jowar (sorghum) roti adds magnesium and makes the meal entirely gluten-free.
item001.healthBenefit: Tofu is a complete protein, supporting tissue repair overnight. Jowar is known to improve digestion.
instructions: Gently press the crumbled tofu to remove excess water.
Heat oil in a pan over medium heat.
Sauté onions until translucent (3 minutes). Add tomatoes and cook until soft.
Add turmeric, cumin powder, salt, and pepper; mix well.
Add the crumbled tofu and stir gently, cooking for about 5-7 minutes until heated through.
Prepare Jowar rotis by mixing flour with hot water and rolling thinly; cook on a dry tawa.
Serve the Tofu Bhurji hot with the Jowar rotis.

item002.title: Vegetable Clear Soup with Brown Rice
item002.description: A light, broth-based soup filled with seasonal vegetables, served alongside a small portion of brown rice. Significance: Excellent choice for a light dinner, promoting easy digestion and hydration before sleep, aiding weight management.
item002.healthBenefit: Hydrating and nutrient-dense without high fat or calorie load, perfect for evening satiety.
ingredients: 1/2 cup cooked brown rice (served on the side)
Salt, pepper, 1/2 tsp light soy sauce (optional)
instructions: In a pot, bring the vegetable broth to a gentle boil.
Add ginger paste and the harder vegetables (carrots, beans). Simmer for 5 minutes.
Add the softer vegetables (zucchini, spring onion whites) and cook until tender-crisp (3-4 minutes).
Season with salt, pepper, and soy sauce if using.
Do not overcook to maintain nutrient integrity.
Serve the hot soup in a large bowl with the measured portion of brown rice on the side.

item003.title: Rajma Masala with Minimal Ghee
item003.description: Kidney beans cooked in a rich, mildly spiced tomato-onion gravy. Significance: A powerhouse of slow-releasing carbohydrates and fiber, promoting sustained fullness throughout the night and aiding in cholesterol management.
item003.healthBenefit: The high fiber content directly correlates with improved lipid profiles, lowering LDL cholesterol.
ingredients: Salt and chili powder to taste
instructions: Heat oil/ghee in a deep pan over medium heat.
Sauté onions until deep golden brown (this is key for flavor).
Add ginger-garlic paste and cook for 1 minute.
Add tomato puree, rajma masala, chili powder, and salt; cook until the mixture thickens and oil surfaces.
Add the cooked rajma and water.
Cover and simmer on low heat for 20 minutes, stirring occasionally.
Serve hot, ideally with a side salad or a small portion of plain rice.

item004.title: Grilled Chicken Breast with Sautéed Greens
item004.description: Lean chicken breast seasoned with Indian herbs and grilled/baked, served with sautéed spinach or kale. Significance: Optimal for muscle repair and retention during overnight fasting, as it's extremely high in protein and low in everything else.
item004.healthBenefit: Provides over 40g of pure, lean protein necessary for overnight recovery with negligible carbohydrates.
ingredients: 1/2 teaspoon cumin powder, 1/2 teaspoon coriander powder
instructions: Marinate chicken with lemon juice, ginger-garlic paste, cumin, coriander, salt, and pepper for at least 30 minutes.
Grill or bake the chicken at 400°F (200°C) for 18-22 minutes, flipping halfway, until cooked through.
Heat olive oil in a pan; add spinach and sauté briefly until just wilted (2 minutes). Season with salt.
Slice the grilled chicken breast.
Serve the sliced chicken immediately alongside the sautéed greens.

item005.title: Methi Thepla with Yogurt Dip (Digestive Aid)
item005.description: Soft, whole wheat flatbreads seasoned with fenugreek leaves (methi). Significance: Fenugreek is traditionally used to aid digestion and is known to help manage blood sugar levels due to its fiber content.
item005.healthBenefit: Methi seeds/leaves contain saponins and fiber that have been shown in studies to help manage glucose absorption.
ingredients: 1/2 cup finely chopped fresh methi leaves
instructions: In a bowl, combine atta, chopped methi, turmeric, salt, and 1 tsp oil.
Knead into a soft dough using warm water; let it rest for 20 minutes.
Divide the dough into equal small balls.
Roll each ball into a thin circle (thepla).
Cook on a medium-hot tawa, brushing a light layer of oil on both sides until golden brown spots appear.
Whisk yogurt with a pinch of salt for the dip.
Serve 2 theplas hot with the yogurt dip.

item006.title: Mushroom and Pea Curry with Brown Rice (Low Fat)
item006.description: A flavorful curry using mushrooms and peas in a tomato-onion base with minimal added fat. Significance: Mushrooms offer B vitamins and selenium, while the overall dish is kept low in fat, supporting heart health.
item006.healthBenefit: Mushrooms provide immune-supporting nutrients like Beta-glucans. The low-fat preparation keeps the calorie count controlled.
instructions: Sauté onion paste in 1/2 teaspoon of oil until golden brown.
Add ginger-garlic paste, cook for 1 minute.
Add tomato puree and curry powder; cook until oil separates.
Add mushrooms and peas; cook covered for 5 minutes until tender.
Add water and salt; simmer for 10 minutes.
Serve the curry hot over the pre-cooked brown rice.

item007.title: Paneer & Bell Pepper Skewers (Air-Fried)
item007.description: Cubes of cottage cheese and colorful bell peppers marinated in yogurt and spices, then air-fried or baked. Significance: A high-protein, low-carb dinner option that retains flavor without excessive oil, supporting muscle health.
item007.healthBenefit: Paneer provides casein protein, which digests slowly, offering a sustained release of amino acids overnight.
instructions: Marinate paneer and bell pepper cubes in yogurt, tandoori masala, ginger paste, salt, and lemon juice for 30 minutes.
Thread the paneer and peppers alternately onto the skewers.
Preheat air fryer to 375°F (190°C).
Arrange skewers in the air fryer basket (do not overcrowd).
Air fry for 10-12 minutes, turning halfway, until lightly browned.
Alternatively, bake at 400°F (200°C) for 15-20 minutes.
Serve hot, perhaps with a side of mint chutney.

item008.title: Masoor Dal Khichdi (Easy to Digest)
item008.description: A comforting, one-pot dish combining rice and red lentils (masoor dal) cooked until very soft with minimal spices. Significance: A staple for gentle nutrition; the soft texture and simple ingredients make it extremely easy on the stomach, ideal for recovery or sensitive systems.
item008.healthBenefit: Masoor dal cooks quickly and breaks down easily, providing essential amino acids and iron in a highly digestible form.
ingredients: 1 teaspoon ghee (optional, can be omitted for vegan)
instructions: Wash rice and dal together thoroughly.
In a pressure cooker, heat ghee (if using); add hing and turmeric.
Add the washed rice and dal mixture; sauté for 1 minute.
Add 2 cups of water and salt; stir well.
Pressure cook for 3-4 whistles, then let the pressure release naturally.
Once open, stir well until the consistency is porridge-like.
Serve hot with a dash of lemon juice.

item009.title: Vegetable Dalia (Broken Wheat Porridge)
item009.description: A savory, thick porridge made from cracked wheat cooked with finely chopped vegetables. Significance: Dalia is a whole grain, providing excellent fiber and B vitamins; it is very low on the glycemic index, beneficial for long-term health.
item009.healthBenefit: Its high fiber content aids in regulating bowel movements and maintaining stable blood sugar levels.
instructions: Dry roast the dalia in a pan for 2-3 minutes until slightly fragrant; set aside.
Heat oil in a pot; add cumin seeds and let them splutter.
Add chopped vegetables and sauté for 5 minutes.
Add the roasted dalia and water; bring to a boil.
Reduce heat, cover, and simmer for 15-20 minutes until the dalia is soft and the water is absorbed.
Season with salt and pepper.
Serve hot as a light, whole-grain meal.

item010.title: Spinach & Cottage Cheese (Palak Paneer) Stir-fry
item010.description: A reduced-cream version of Palak Paneer, focusing on sautéed spinach and paneer cubes seasoned with traditional spices. Significance: Excellent source of calcium and iron; low in simple carbs, making it a satisfying, nutrient-dense choice for the final meal.
item010.healthBenefit: The combination of Vitamin C (from tomatoes/spices) and Iron (from spinach) aids in better iron absorption.
instructions: Lightly sauté paneer cubes in a dry pan until lightly golden; set aside.
Heat oil/ghee; add onion puree and cook until brown.
Add tomato puree and ginger-garlic paste; cook until the raw smell disappears.
Add garam masala, salt, and the pureed spinach.
Cook the spinach base for 5-7 minutes, stirring frequently.
Gently fold in the sautéed paneer cubes.
Simmer for 2 minutes, allowing the paneer to absorb the flavor.
Serve warm, avoiding heavy breads to maintain low carb intake.
